edu.luc.cs.trull.demo.rmi
Class PeerImpl

java.lang.Object
  java.rmi.server.RemoteObject
      java.rmi.server.RemoteServer
          java.rmi.server.UnicastRemoteObject
              edu.luc.cs.trull.demo.rmi.PeerImpl
All Implemented Interfaces:
Peer, java.rmi.Remote, RemotePropertyChangeListener, java.io.Serializable
public class PeerImpl
extends java.rmi.server.UnicastRemoteObject
implements Peer

An RMI-based component suitable for a peer-to-peer architecture. The peer's behavior is provided by a Trull component. The peer implementation creates its own registry on the local host and registers itself.

See Also:
Peer, Component, Serialized Form

Constructor Detail

PeerImpl

public PeerImpl(Component component,
                java.lang.String selfHost,
                java.lang.String selfName,
                java.lang.String peerHost,
                java.lang.String peerName)
         throws java.rmi.RemoteException
Parameters:
component - the Trull component that provides this peer's behavior.
selfHost - the host name where this local peer is running.
selfName - the name of this local peer object.
peerHost - the host name where the remote peer is running.
peerName - the name of the remote peer object.
Method Detail

addPeerListener

void addPeerListener()
Add the peer as a listener to the expr. Events are sent to the peer asynchronously via the remoteEventQueue.

bindPeer

protected boolean bindPeer()
Try to bind the peer and report whether the peer is ready.

bindSelf

protected void bindSelf()
Create a registry on the local host and register myself.

               throws java.rmi.RemoteException

public void propertyChange(java.beans.PropertyChangeEvent event)
                    throws java.rmi.RemoteException
Send any incoming events from outside to the expr.

Specified by:
propertyChange in interface RemotePropertyChangeListener
Throws:
java.rmi.RemoteException - if any exception occurs on the remote side.

start

public void start()
           throws java.lang.InterruptedException
This method first sets up an RMI registry on selfHost and registers the newly created peer on the registry under selfName. It then waits for the peer peerName on peerHost to become available. Finally, it hooks the remote peer up as a listener to the events sent out by the local peer.

Specified by:
start in interface Peer
Throws:
java.lang.InterruptedException

waitForPeer

protected void waitForPeer()
Wait for the peer to become available on its host. Once the peer becomes available, tell the peer that we are available.
